bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, October 9, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg informs Hench that Kean, Stitt, and Russell will receive the Gorgas award. He quotes part of the citation for Kean.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, October 9, 1942
div1.opener:
B
BISMARCK HOTEL
· CHICAGO ·
Oct. 9, 1942
Dear Phil,
div1.p:
Today I received Col.
Hunter's promised letter.
He was certainly cagey in
the manner in which he
phrased it. I'll have it
copied on Monday when I
get home and send you a
copy.

I had a nice letter
from Col. Hume today saying
that the Executive Council of
the ass'n of military Surgeons
had approved of the three
recipients for the Gorgas medal
this year. Gen'l Kean, Admiral Stitt,
General Russell!

Kean's citation reads in
part “He was father, said Surgeon
General Ireland, of the three administrative
measures upon which the medical
Dept of the army rested in the
First World War - creation of the
medical Reserve Corps (1908). Organization
at parent institutions of the Army's
base hospitals. (1916) Development
of the Field medical supply depots
of the army (1903)” “He has
done more for the advancement
of the interests of the Department
than any officer who ever
belonged to the corps.”

I've written Col. Hume about
the “Epitome” project and plan
to see him early next week.
I think he'll like it and helps
us.

I certainly enjoyed my
stay at Camp Carson and
hope you may get to San Antonio
for the ass'n meeting November
5th in which case I'll see you.

Give my best to your
swell wife - and you'll be
hearing from me.
